stance_1: Cost limits my ability to buy quality meat
justification: The interviewee states that cost often prevents them from obtaining the quality meat they desire, making cost a direct barrier to quality.

stance_1: Cost limits my ability to buy quality meat
stance_2: I want to support local, sustainable farms
justification: The interviewee explicitly mentions wanting to support local, sustainable farms, but cost is often a limiting factor.
The interviewee states that health is a main motivation for eating meat regularly.

stance_2: I eat vegetarian dinners some days
justification: Choosing vegetarian dinners some days can be seen as part of a health-motivated, balanced diet.

stance_2: I balance meat with grains and beans
justification: The interviewee explicitly links health motivation to balancing meat with grains and beans.

stance_2: I want to support local, sustainable farms
justification: The interviewee connects caring about quality with a desire to support sustainable, local farms.

stance_2: I feel satisfied after eating meat
justification: The interviewee states that eating meat makes them feel more satisfied, supporting regular consumption.
The interviewee explicitly connects enjoyment of taste with their regular meat eating.

stance_2: I eat vegetarian dinners some days
justification: Having vegetarian dinners some days implies not eating meat on those days, in contrast to eating meat most days.

stance_2: I balance meat with grains and beans
justification: The interviewee describes balancing meat with other foods as part of their routine.

stance_1: I eat vegetarian dinners some days
stance_2: I balance meat with grains and beans
justification: Vegetarian meals are part of the strategy to balance meat with grains, beans, and other foods.

stance_1: I want to support local, sustainable farms
justification: The interviewee explicitly says that supporting local, sustainable farms is limited by the expense of their meat.
